content:
Section 212(a)(3)(B)(i) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include aliens identified in the terrorist screening database, with an exception for lawful permanent residents. SEC. 2 amends the Immigration and Nationality Act to exempt lawful permanent residents from deportation if identified in the terrorist screening database. SEC. 3 provides waivers for aliens in the same database. Section 212(d)(3) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow for the granting of nonimmigrant visas on a case-by-case basis for national security interests. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow the Secretary of Homeland Security to grant nonimmigrant visas on a case-by-case basis for national security interests, with the unanimous concurrence of key officials. SEC. 4. UNAVAILABILITY OF CERTAIN IMMIGRATION BENEFITS TO ALIENS IDENTIFIED IN TERRORIST SCREENING DATABASE. (a) Amendment to asylum provision under the Immigration and Nationality Act to include new category (IX).
(b) Amendment to withholding of removal provision to include new inadmissibility and deportability criteria.
(c) Amendment to cancellation of removal provision for certain permanent residents regarding inadmissibility. (c) Cancellation of Removal. Section 240A(a) of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include new criteria for certain permanent residents regarding inadmissibility and deportability. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include new criteria for cancellation of removal for certain nonpermanent residents, specifying inadmissibility and deportability exceptions. Additionally, the criteria for voluntary departure of aliens is revised by the Secretary of Homeland Security. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include new criteria for cancellation of removal for certain nonpermanent residents, specifying inadmissibility and deportability exceptions. The Secretary of Homeland Security revises the criteria for voluntary departure of aliens, prohibiting departure for aliens previously found inadmissible under specific sections. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to include new criteria for adjustment of status and registry, specifying inadmissibility and deportability exceptions. The Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to change the terms from "Attorney General" to "Secretary of Homeland Security" and to specify new criteria for inadmissibility and deportability exceptions related to section 212(a)(3)(B)(i)(IX) and section 237(a)(4)(B). The Secretary of Homeland Security is required to revise regulations implementing the United Nations Convention Against Torture within 120 days of the Act's enactment. The Secretary of Homeland Security must revise regulations implementing the United Nations Convention Against Torture within 120 days of the Act's enactment, excluding certain aliens from protection and making them ineligible for withholding or deferral of removal under immigration laws. The revised regulations exclude certain aliens from protection under the United Nations Convention Against Torture, making them ineligible for withholding or deferral of removal under immigration laws. The regulations also allow for reopening and readjudication of past determinations, applying to acts or conditions regardless of when they occurred. SEC. 5. EXPEDITED REMOVAL OF ALIENS INADMISSIBLE OR DEPORTABLE ON SECURITY AND RELATED GROUNDS. Section 238 of the Immigration and Nationality Act is amended to allow for the removal of aliens who are not permanent residents and are inadmissible or deportable on security or related grounds. The Secretary of Homeland Security has the authority to determine the inadmissibility or deportability of such aliens. The Secretary of Homeland Security has the authority to determine the inadmissibility or deportability of aliens under specific sections of the Immigration and Nationality Act and issue orders of removal accordingly. The Secretary of Homeland Security can determine the inadmissibility or deportability of aliens under certain sections of the Immigration and Nationality Act and issue removal orders accordingly. This includes aliens described in specific subsections for whom orders may or may not be issued. Aliens can be deemed inadmissible or deportable under specific sections of the Immigration and Nationality Act, leading to the issuance of removal orders. This applies to aliens who have not been granted a waiver under section 212(d)(3)(C) and were not lawfully admitted for permanent residence or had conditional permanent resident status at the time proceedings began. Aliens who are inadmissible or deportable under certain sections of the Immigration and Nationality Act may face removal orders. This applies to those who were not lawfully admitted for permanent residence or had conditional permanent resident status when proceedings started. Expedited proceedings will be conducted according to regulations set by the Secretary of Homeland Security, ensuring the alien is informed of charges and provided with the opportunity for representation at no cost to the government. The alien facing removal orders must be given notice of charges, the opportunity for representation by chosen counsel, the chance to inspect evidence and rebut charges, verification of identity, and maintenance of a record for judicial review. The alien facing removal orders must be given notice of charges, the opportunity for representation by chosen counsel, the chance to inspect evidence and rebut charges, verification of identity, and maintenance of a record for judicial review. Additionally, the final order of removal must not be adjudicated by the same person who issues the charges, and the Secretary of Homeland Security must wait 14 calendar days before executing any removal order to allow for judicial review under section 242. The alien must be given notice of charges, the opportunity for representation, chance to inspect evidence, and verification of identity before facing removal orders. The Secretary of Homeland Security must wait 14 calendar days before executing any removal order to allow for judicial review under section 242. Additionally, no alien adjudicated inadmissible or deportable shall be eligible for discretionary relief from removal. SEC. 6. EFFECTIVE DATE; APPLICABILITY. This Act and its amendments will take effect upon enactment and apply to all individuals in the terrorist screening database after that date.
